image.altText: woman looking out window

props.synopsis: There’s a push for stricter regulation of the massage industry, after a practitioner was able to keep indecently assaulting his clients after being reported to police and an industry body. Data shows the issue could be widespread.

title.children: Is this self-regulated industry a breeding ground for predators?

image.altText: Two police officers standing on a street

props.synopsis: A person has been rushed to hospital in a critical condition after they were stabbed during a serious domestic assault, police say.

title.children: Stabbing victim in critical condition after suspected domestic assault in Adelaide's north-west

image.altText: A Facebook photo of former professional cyclist Melissa Hoskins.

props.synopsis: Loved ones of Olympic cyclist Melissa Hoskins will be given the chance to deliver victim impact statements at the next court appearance of Rohan Dennis, who last month pleaded guilty over the incident which resulted in his wife's death.

title.children: Court anticipates victim impact statements following death of Melissa Hoskins

image.altText: A giant burrowing cockroach resting on its back in cupped hands

props.synopsis: While people pay good money to get rid of cockroaches and other creepy-crawlies, Kris Messenger has dedicated her life to spruiking the benefits of bugs. But she says demand for them as pets can have an impact on ecosystems if they are poached from the wild.

title.children: This $80 native cockroach is a popular pet, but there's a dark side to the industry

image.altText: A man in a white coat in a dark room with purple light looking at seedlings

props.synopsis: Tomato seedling trade has once again been halted after seedlings were moved from South Australia to Victoria without a plant health certificate.

title.children: Tomato grower defends unauthorised transport of infected seedling

image.altText: A man holds a photo of an elderly woman

props.synopsis: A 93-year-old man has been found mentally unfit to stand trial for the murder of his wife, and therefore not guilty.

title.children: Children of 85yo woman killed by her husband can't forgive 'evil act'

image.altText: Anthony Albanese calls for reform and renewal in the health and education sectors

props.synopsis: Two more states have agreed to sign on to the federal government's new school funding agreement, which will see the Commonwealth lift its share of public school funding to 25 per cent.

title.children: Significant progress to ending the school funding wars as two more states sign on

image.altText: Two power transmission towers in the middle on an open field with a sunrise in the background.,

props.synopsis: Six months after they were mothballed by their parent company two diesel generators could be turned back on to help power South Australia this summer.

title.children: AEMO permitted to switch on South Australian diesel generators during shortfall

image.altText: A court build with a columned verandah and a blue coloured building behind

props.synopsis: A lawyer whose experience of sexual harassment prompted the dismissal of a South Australian magistrate doubts the findings of a second review of the legal profession will spark immediate change.

title.children: Sexual harassment still ‘systemic’ in legal profession, says lawyer

image.altText: A semi-trailer trailer on fire at night

props.synopsis: A semitrailer carrying toilet paper catches fire while driving through dry farmland and pine forests in south-western Victoria, but "luck" and cooperation prevent the blaze from causing a much larger disaster.

title.children: Truck carrying toilet paper bursts into flames but bushfire prevented

image.altText: Pizza on a cutting board.

props.synopsis: A franchisee running more than a dozen Domino's pizza outlets in two states has been banned from employing trainees and apprentices at 12 SA stores, after an investigation by a workplace watchdog.

title.children: Domino's pizza franchisee banned from hiring trainees across 12 SA stores

image.altText: A sign in an outback town which says "Welcome to Oodnadatta, Australia's hottest driest town."

props.synopsis: Residents of Oodnadatta, one of Australia's hottest towns, have suffered through two power outages this week as temperatures soared above 40 degrees Celsius.

title.children: Power outages hit one of Australia's hottest towns as temps soar above 40

image.altText: GettyImages-1536734557

props.synopsis: A reworked serving style by Madison Keys could be the weapon that helps the American halt the power of Aryna Sabalenka.

title.children: How a reworked serve and a powerful forehand could decide tonight's final

image.altText: an old photograph of women working in an old telephone exchange, with basic computers and panels.

props.synopsis: Gone are the days of manually plugging in cords to connect phone calls but the memories remain for a group of women who brought people closer together.

title.children: Telephonists reminisce 40 years on from secrets, party lines and cyclones

image.altText: Actor Hugh Grant has reignited his feud with controversial journalist Piers Morgan.

props.synopsis: The English actor was forced to settle in the same lawsuit with NGN that Prince Harry reached a settlement with this week.

title.children: Actor Hugh Grant calls for police to investigate UK tabloid paper

props.synopsis: Just as Donald Trump is galvanising the world with all his wildness, Anthony Albanese has clearly decided that stability and calm is the best persona he can offer voters as our own election approaches.

title.children: Australia's election will ride the shock waves of Trump 2.0

image.altText: A Maori woman wears traditional necklace

props.synopsis: The dialling back of Indigenous rights will be high on the agenda for Invasion Day rallies this year, according to protest organisers who say it's a global "phenomenon" also happening to overseas colonised nations.

title.children: 'Rise of the far right': What people are protesting this Australia Day

image.altText: A man in khaki uniform, seen through mesh inside a van

props.synopsis: Hundreds of migrants in the United States have been arrested, and others flown out of the country on military aircraft, as the White House says President Donald Trump's promised deportation operation has started.

title.children: Hundreds of migrants arrested as White House says deportation scheme underway

image.altText: A woman, man and young man stand at the waterfront holding awards.

props.synopsis: The Aussies in the running to become the 2025 Australian of the Year are improving support for children, cultural understanding, disability awareness and employment, and sustainability.

title.children: Meet the 2025 Australian of the Year nominees

props.synopsis: Around the clock coverage of news events as they break at home and abroad.

title.children: ABC News Channel live

image.altText: trump holds paper signed

props.synopsis: Global health experts fear Donald Trump's plan to withdraw the US from the World Health Organization could roll back decades-long gains made in fighting diseases and increase pandemic risks.

title.children: US exit from World Health Organization 'darkest day' for global health

image.altText: House destroyed by fire in Arthur River

props.synopsis: Within two hours, major blazes broke out across the state as gusty winds and a heatwave combined for a dangerous outbreak.

title.children: Four homes lost as WA bushfire emergency continues

image.altText: A black and white photo of a group of people

props.synopsis: The murder of a dashing earl in Kenya shocked his pack of hard-partying aristocratic friends. Was it a robbery gone wrong? An assassination? Or the violent culmination of a love triangle fuelled by jealousy, suspicion and many, many gin and tonics?

title.children: 'To hell with husbands': The aristocratic love triangle that ended in murder

image.altText: An image of a Rex plane sitting outside Parliament House

props.synopsis: With the federal government now becoming Rex's largest secured creditor, experts are asking whether the airline may end up in public ownership.

title.children: Australia hasn't had a publicly owned airline for 30 years. That could be about to change

image.altText: A stingray jumping out of a blue ocean.

props.synopsis: An island paradise in the Great Barrier Reef is home to giant stingrays leaping out of the water and momentarily "flying" metres above the surface.

title.children: Stingray zoomies have scientists baffled

image.altText: Jurien Bay Medical Centre sign

props.synopsis: Despite buying a house in town the doctor made the difficult choice to move on and complete her training as a specialist GP.

title.children: Jurien Bay's only female doctor leaves due to a bureaucratic bungle

image.altText: High-vis workers on a cherry picker next to power lines with Perth skyline in the background

props.synopsis: Thousands of WA residents are without electricity after overnight drizzle sparked pole-top fires, causing power outages.

title.children: Perth hit by widespread power outages sparked by summer rain

image.altText: Supporters of PM Modi sitting together on the ground wearing orange scarves, and masks of Modi's face

props.synopsis: Imagine having the federal, state and local elections all held at the same time across the country. If that sounds like a daunting task, imagine it in a nation less than half the size of Australia, but with a billion voters.

title.children: A battle is brewing in India over the way almost a billion people vote

image.altText: A composite image of three TikTok screens showing sellers holding and looking at cherries.

props.synopsis: Tasmanian cherries are being sold online in hyped buying markets not unlike TV infomercials.

title.children: How TikTok is helping sell Tasmanian cherries to Asian customers

image.altText: A shirtless man cycles through a park.

props.synopsis: The weather bureau is predicting a reprieve from heatwave conditions in parts of Queensland, but temperatures will still be brutal in some areas.

title.children: Heatwave set to ease for some Queenslanders, but warnings issued

image.altText: A Chinese woman offers a prayer in front of  flowers.

props.synopsis: The attack sparked debate in China about the country's patriotic education.

title.children: Man sentenced to death for killing 10-year-old child in China

image.altText: Electricians place solar panels on roof

props.synopsis: The most recent data shows apprenticeship numbers haven't kept pace with population growth, with more than half of apprentices not completing their training.

title.children: What the data tells us about Australia's apprentice shortage

image.altText: A stack of books with an open book on top; a wall lined with books in the background

props.synopsis: Small presses have dominated literary prizes in recent years, and larger publishers are buying them out. What do these acquisitions mean for the local publishing industry?

title.children: Why multinational takeovers of indie publishers are 'bad for readers'

image.altText: A middle-aged woman wearing a floral top and star of david necklace and brown hair smiles at the camera.

props.synopsis: Amid the concern of hate crimes occurring throughout Sydney and beyond, many community leaders and educational organisations are focusing on what connects us rather than divides us.

title.children: Sydney rabbi sent messages of 'compassion and care' amid hateful attacks

image.altText: The Purdue Pharma branded logo seen on the side of a grey building roof

props.synopsis: The pharmaceutical company's owners have agreed to pay US7.4 billion ($11.7 billion) and relinquish ownership of the company.

title.children: Purdue Pharma to pay billions to settle OxyContin crisis lawsuit
